awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Microfluidic Technology for Full-Page Digital Braille & Tactile Graphics Display
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to reduce the burden of accessing information for the 1.5 million blind people in the United States by making a full page of refreshable braille text and tactile graphics available in a device resembling a tablet computer. This assistive technology will provide increased access to braille and enable blind students to read digitized spatial content including mathematical equations, graphs, and figures with their fingers, creating parity with their sighted counterparts interested in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields. The proposed product will improve braille literacy, opportunities in STEM careers, and ultimately lead to the employment success and independence of blind Americans. 

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project relies on microfluidic technology to create a highly manufacturable device that combines an underlying rigid layer supplying pneumatic signals and an overlying soft layer containing membrane actuators at braille spacing. The successful commercialization of a full-page refreshable braille and tactile graphic display requires very tight packaging, high refresh rates, and a materials/manufacturing solution that scales gracefully to a tablet-size product. The proposed solution harnesses existing capabilities in the microfluidics lab-on-a-chip industry and deploys pneumatic actuators to achieve a scalable design. The development project involves identifying compromises to device refresh rates by characterizing timing constraints of the integrated microfluidic chips and membrane actuators. The results of the technical objectives will demonstrate the scalability of the innovation for achieving a full-page refreshable braille and tactile graphics display.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project demonstrated by proof-of-concept a novel tactile display technology based on microfluidics that is suitable for scale-up into an affordable multiline refreshable braille and tactile graphics display. For blind people, access to information is limited by the high cost and inherent shortcomings of state-of-the-art assistive technologies. Current Refreshable Braille Displays can only raise a single line of braille text at a time and cannot render graphical content (e.g., graphs, maps, charts) in tactile form. While text-to-speech and audio-books are now inexpensive and widely available, speech cannot substitute for braille and tactile graphical content in the comprehension, retention, and manipulation of information. Blind students in particular are underserved in the increasingly digitized education system, especially in STEM subjects in which spatial content is critical to understanding subject matter. An affordable large-area tactile display supporting multiple lines of braille and tactile graphics is critical to improving access to information for blind people and ultimately improving their opportunities in education and the workplace.  

In this project, multiple microfluidic chips and a large array of pneumatically-driven actuators were assembled into a single, highly-manufacturable tactile display component that supported rendering multiple lines of braille and tactile graphics. In particular, the component combined 4 microfluidic chips with a uniform grid of 840 pneumatically-driven actuators with 2.5 mm center-to-center spacing. The device leveraged the novel microfluidic logic functionality of the attached chips to enable all 840 actuators to be refreshed one row at a time using only 58 electropneumatic valves. Rigid tactile pins with diameters of 1.3 mm were combined with pneumatic actuators and shown to achieve deflections of at least 0.25 mm under 150 mN loads, meeting industry-standard braille specifications. The total device refresh time from start of refresh to the lowering of the final tactile dot was approximately 3 seconds. Moreover, an array of custom electropneumatic valves and a fluidic logic circuit were proven to be easily integrated into the same substrate as the microfluidic chips and pneumatic actuators, further reducing the cost and complexity of the novel tactile display technology. The success of this Phase I project motivates the development and commercialization of a full-scale multiline braille and tactile graphics display.
